jorisvandenbossche commented on pull request #5578: ARROW-6778: [C++] Support zero copy cast for DurationType
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5578
 
 
   https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6778
   
   This is only zero copy cast of int64 <-> duration. Not yet unit conversion (duration[s] -> duration[ms]).

jorisvandenbossche commented on pull request #5578: ARROW-6778: [C++] Support cast for DurationType
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5578#discussion_r331470223
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/compute/kernels/cast.cc
 ##########
 @@ -477,13 +477,19 @@ const std::pair<bool, int64_t> kTimeConversionTable[4][4] = {
 
 }  // namespace
 
-template <>
-struct CastFunctor<TimestampType, TimestampType> {
+// <TimestampType, TimestampType> and <DurationType, DurationType>
+template <typename O, typename I>
+struct CastFunctor<
+    O, I,
+    typename std::enable_if<(std::is_base_of<O, TimestampType>::value &&
+                             std::is_base_of<I, TimestampType>::value) ||
+                            (std::is_base_of<O, DurationType>::value &&
+                             std::is_base_of<I, DurationType>::value)>::type> {
   void operator()(FunctionContext* ctx, const CastOptions& options,
 
 Review comment:
   So for some reason, this works for `<TimestampType, TimestampType>`, but not for `<DurationType, DurationType>`. 
   This functions calls `ShiftTime<int64_t, int64_t>` (defined just above), and in there, it is the line
   
   ```
   auto out_data = output->GetMutableValues<out_type>(1);
   ```
   
   that segfaults. But I would think that TimestampType and DurationType have the exact same layout, and should not behave differently?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

pitrou commented on pull request #5578: ARROW-6778: [C++] Support cast for DurationType
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5578#discussion_r331996506
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/compute/kernels/cast.cc
 ##########
 @@ -477,13 +477,19 @@ const std::pair<bool, int64_t> kTimeConversionTable[4][4] = {
 
 }  // namespace
 
-template <>
-struct CastFunctor<TimestampType, TimestampType> {
+// <TimestampType, TimestampType> and <DurationType, DurationType>
+template <typename O, typename I>
+struct CastFunctor<
+    O, I,
+    typename std::enable_if<(std::is_base_of<O, TimestampType>::value &&
+                             std::is_base_of<I, TimestampType>::value) ||
+                            (std::is_base_of<O, DurationType>::value &&
+                             std::is_base_of<I, DurationType>::value)>::type> {
   void operator()(FunctionContext* ctx, const CastOptions& options,
 
 Review comment:
   So, the issue is probably that `is_primitive` (in `arrow/type_traits.h`) returns false for Duration. It should probably be fixed.

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
Currently, duration is not yet supported in basic cast operations (using the python binding from ARROW-5855, currently from my branch, not yet merged):

{code}
In [25]: arr = pa.array([1, 2])

In [26]: arr.cast(pa.duration('s'))  
...
ArrowNotImplementedError: No cast implemented from int64 to duration[s]

In [27]: arr = pa.array([1, 2], pa.duration('s'))  

In [28]: arr.cast(pa.duration('ms'))
...
ArrowNotImplementedError: No cast implemented from duration[s] to duration[ms]
{code}
